events.description: The S&P Global UK Construction PMI rose to 46.4 in January 2026, rebounding from a multi-year low.
The UK government budget which provided clarity for commercial construction firms.

facts.fact_text: The S&P Global UK Construction PMI rose to 46.4 in January 2026.

evidences.evidence_text: The S&P Global UK Construction PMI rose to 46.4 in January 2026, rebounding from December’s five-and-a-half-year low of 40.1 and exceeding market expectations of 42.0.

facts.fact_text: Input price inflation reached a four-month high.

evidences.evidence_text: On the cost side, input price inflation accelerated to a four-month high.

facts.fact_text: Employment in the construction sector continued to decline significantly.

evidences.evidence_text: though employment continued to decline at a marked pace.

claims.claim_text: The slower fall in new orders suggests early signs of stabilization in the construction sector.
claims.author: S&P Global

evidences.evidence_text: Total new orders fell at the slowest rate in three months, suggesting early signs of stabilization

claims.claim_text: Improved post-Budget clarity and investment sentiment recovery helped commercial construction.

evidences.evidence_text: commercial construction showed the smallest decline since May 2025, as some firms cited improved post-Budget clarity and a modest recovery in investment sentiment.

claims.claim_text: Business optimism is at its highest in months but remains historically weak.

evidences.evidence_text: Business optimism improved to its strongest level since May 2025, but confidence remained well below its long-term average.

evidence.evidence_text: some firms cited improved post-Budget clarity and a modest recovery in investment sentiment.
the index signaled a continued contraction in construction activity.
On the cost side, input price inflation accelerated to a four-month high.
though employment continued to decline at a marked pace.
